awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP: Training the Next Generation of Workers and Outreach in Plant Tissue Culture for Crop Improvement Using Genome Editing
awd_abstract_narration:
The Society for In Vitro Biology (SIVB) will hold four workshops at its 2022 and 2023 annual meetings designed to educate participants on the topics of plant tissue culture and genetic engineering. The workshops will target researchers including faculty, students, post-docs, and industry personnel involved in utilizing plant tissue culture and gene insertion techniques for the development of improved crop cultivars. Programs will contain both in-person and virtual content. Following the conferences, presentations and other generated materials will be made available to interested groups who wish to use them for research and educational purposes in classroom teaching or laboratory sessions.

Currently there is a need for experts in the field of plant tissue culture and transformation. Many have spent decades of research and continually seek opportunities to share and disseminate knowledge, good practices and learnings to the emerging group of scientists, especially those in underserved or minority communities who may not have ready access to this information. These workshops serve as a perfect platform and aim to target new and young faculty and industry personnel involved in tissue culture and genetic engineering/genome editing research along with students and community college educators who wish to introduce these topics in the classroom. It is the expectation that organizers will generate sets of informational material that will enable the long-term dissemination of this crucial knowledge. The workshops will impact a diverse community of researchers who are involved in plant tissue culture and genetic engineering/genome editing research activities. It will also ensure that the expertise generated in the area of in vitro plant tissue culture during the 20th century will be successfully passed on to the incoming generations of new researchers and help create a workforce for advancing genome engineering and crop improvement technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SOCIETY FOR IN VITRO BIOLOGY, INCORPORATED

por.por_cntn:
The Society for In Vitro Biology (SIVB), founded in 1946 as the Tissue Culture Association, is a professional society dedicated to fostering exchange of knowledge of in vitro biology of cells, tissues, and organs from both plants and animals, including humans. SIVB fosters the scientific and technical growth of its members, conducts biotechnology research to understand biology at the cellular and developmental level, and promotes expands, and supports the scientific knowledge base for the benefit of society. Our mission, representing biotechnology research in all living organisms, to be recognized as a progressive leader in advancing the breadth and depth of understanding of in vitro science.

 

SIVB successfully held its annual conference in San Diego from June 4th to 7th, 2022, followed by the subsequent year's meeting in Norfolk, Virginia, from June 10th to 14th, 2023. Integral to these conferences were four workshops designed to enhance the knowledge base of scientists and researchers in the fields of plant tissue culture and genetic engineering. These educational workshops were specifically tailored for a diverse group of researchers, encompassing faculty members, students, postdoctoral fellows, and professionals from the industry. The primary focus was on the application of in vitro plant tissue culture, plant transformation and genome editing techniques for the functional analysis of genes in model and crop plants and the development of improved crops.

Our goal was to find avenues where experts in the field can share and disseminate their expertise, best practices, and insights to the emerging group of scientists, especially those that might lack direct access to such valuable information. To ensure inclusivity, the live sessions were recorded and made available virtually to registrants who could not be present physically, and then uploaded to the Society's YouTube channel, thereby broadening the reach and facilitating easier access to this knowledge.

These videos can be found as follows:

Year 1

  • Why DoE? DoE Principles and DoE Software: https://youtu.be/4ppiR7wDvYU
  • DOE Experiment Walkthrough - 2022 In Vitro Biology Meeting: https://youtu.be/z9seuJiZ2XI

Year 2

  • Design of Experiment (DOE) Workshop – Part II (Mixture Designs; R Statistical Software: https://youtu.be/BQQyat-P6cY 
  • Principles and Best Practices for Plant Genome Engineering Workshop: https://youtu.be/X1LGM1810T0

 

In addition, abstracts are made freely available as follows:

  • For 2022: https://sivb.org/meetings/2022-program.html. Links to all abstracts can be found here.
  • For 2023, the SIVB abstract issue was transitioned into a post meeting proceedings which includes the scientific abstracts of all presentations: https://link.springer.com/journal/11626/volumes-and-issues/59-1/supplement

 

By making these materials available publicly to interested groups who wish to use them for research and educational purposes in classroom teaching or laboratory sessions, we hope to increase understanding of these techniques and their use for both basic and applied plant research.


For further information about these programs, interested parties may contact the SIVB Business Office at sivb@sivb.org.


Last Modified: 08/30/2024
Modified by: Michele G Schultz
